Loaded noble metal redispersion is an important way to solve catalyst sintering. However, how to redisperse at low temperatures or carbon-based noble catalysts is a difficult problem. In this paper, we report this phenomenon occurring on PdCu alloy catalysts, where small-sized PdCu alloys can be realized from sintered large-sized PdCu alloys on carbon supports in a CO/O2 atmosphere. The mechanism of redispersion is elucidated by XPS, TEM and DFT calculations. The main reason for the redispersion is the formation of the PdCuOx intermediate, which can easily migrate to the nearby catalyst surface and then be reduced to smaller PdCu alloy nanoparticles. This work provides a deeper understanding of the redispersion phenomenon and provides certain applications in industry. Graphical abstrtact Image, graphical abstract Keywords PdCu alloy Low temperature redispersion CO oxidation DFT calculation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Supported noble metal catalysts have been widely used in industry due to their high catalytic activity, high catalytic selectivity, and excellent catalytic performance. Commonly used noble metal catalysts are Pt, Pd and Au, etc. Among them, Pd-based catalysts or alloy catalysts are used in hydrogenation/dehydrogenation reactions [1], purification of automobile pollutants [2], low temperature fuel cell reactions [3], formation of CC bonds and activation of CH bonds [4], etc. However, sintering of supported noble metals is also unavoidable. In order to increase industrial catalyst lifetime, it becomes particularly important to suppress the rate of change of noble metal particles or to redisperse the deactivated catalyst. The traditional method for noble metal regeneration is to burn off the carbon carrier, recover the noble metal, and re-prepare the catalyst. The disadvantage of this method is high energy consumption and long cycle. In addition, the use of toxic and harmful organic solvents cannot be avoided in the regeneration process. Therefore, methods utilizing in-situ redispersion of catalysts that will reverse the sintering process and fully/partially restore catalytic activity are necessary. In situ regeneration of sintered catalysts by redispersion is currently not common. At present, the schemes of in-situ redispersion include redox method, oxychlorination method and halogenated hydrocarbon heat treatment method. Among them, the oxidation–reduction cycle technology is one of the most widely used redispersion methods in industry. It mainly uses the alternating atmosphere of oxygen and hydrogen to treat the catalyst [5]. Farrauto and Schwank et al. investigated the deactivation and regeneration of a series of Pd/Rh catalysts using oxidation and reduction treatments at 500–700 °C [6–9]. Normand et al. carried out the Pt-Sn/Al2O3 catalyst at 400 °C in an O2 H2 atmosphere for 6 consecutive times of redox [10]. The addition of Sn redispersed the Pt metal particles, but also inhibited the activity of the Pt catalyst [11]. A similar phenomenon occurs in Pt-Re catalyst. Oxychlorination can also be used for catalyst regeneration. Rochester et al. treated Pt-Re/Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts with alternating cycles of oxychlorination of 1,2-dichloropropane at 550 °C and H2 atmosphere at 400 °C [12]. The noble metal Pt particles are reduced from 70 nm to about 20 nm. Anderson et al. treated sintered deactivated Pd-Rh and Pt-Rh catalysts with 1,2-dichloropropane as a chlorine source for oxychlorination [13,14]. However, oxidative chlorination is not effective for all noble metals. Yuan et al. used the chloride-oxychlorination method to redisperse/regenerate the sintered Au/AC catalyst [15,16], and investigated the performance of the regenerated Au/AC catalyst by acetylene hydrochlorination. The results showed that the activity of the catalyst basically recovered to initial level. Hardacre et al. treated the Au/AC catalyst with CH3X (X=Cl, Br, I), and found that the size of the gold nanoparticles became significantly smaller [17]. The above method can redisperse the sintered noble metal catalyst, but there is a general problem. Processing in a high temperature atmosphere is not only energy-intensive, but not all traditional supports are stable under the required processing conditions [18,19], such as carbon-based supports, high temperature treatment is prone to carbon deposition and deactivation, which limits its applicability. Furthermore, catalysts treated with these redispersion methods may be further deactivated due to chlorine poisoning. Therefore, how to redisperse carbon-based noble catalysts at low temperature is a research hotspot, and it is necessary to explore an economical and concise method that can be widely used in carbon-supported noble metal catalysts. CO gas has been used to tune the coordination structure of noble metals. Meng et al. synthesized PdAu/SiO2 catalysts, and used the CO adsorption/desorption process to control the cluster coordination structure of Pd [20]. However, the application of the redispersion strategy under COO2 atmosphere has not been reported. Supported Pd metal particles show great potential in various catalytic reactions due to their efficient utilization of metal atoms. However, the low bonding strength between metal nanoparticles and carbon support leads to agglomeration of metal nanoparticles into larger particles, which greatly reduces the catalytic efficiency. Here, we developed a low-temperature redispersion strategy by treating sintered carbon-supported Pd-based catalysts under COO2 atmosphere to obtain PdCu/AC catalysts with smaller particle size. It is used to evaluate the performance of CO oxidation, and the CO oxidation activity of PdCu/AC catalyst can be basically recovered after redispersion. The redispersion phenomenon was analyzed by TEM and XPS, and a redispersion mechanism was proposed based on the experimental results and DFT calculation results. 2 Experiment 2.1 Experimental materials The experimental materials used in this experiment are: PdCl2 (SinoPlatinum Metals, 99.98%), AC (Hang Zhou Wan Jing New Material), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Macklin, 99.8%), C2H5OH (Aladdin, 99.5%). CO (99.99%), O2 (99.999%), N2 (99.99%) were purchased from Hangzhou Minxing Industry and Trade Gas. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Pretreatment of activated carbon: The carrier used in the catalyst is a coal-based activated carbon carrier (AC). The activated carbon was placed in an appropriate amount of 20% HNO3 solution, refluxed and condensed for 6 h at a temperature of 70 ℃ and a rotation speed of 300 r/min. Wash with an appropriate amount of warm distilled water until slightly acidic or neutral. Then it was dried in a drying oven at 110 ℃ for 12 h. The activated carbon-supported PdCu catalyst was prepared by a step-by-step equal volume impregnation method. The weight loadings of Pd and Cu were 1% Pd and 5% Cu, respectively. Specific steps are as follows: (1) The H2PdCl4 solution was diluted to the saturated water absorption capacity of activated carbon, and was evenly immersed on the carrier through a dropper. After sonication for 30 min, it was left at room temperature for 12 h. Then it was dried in a drying oven at 110 ℃ for 12 h. (2) An appropriate amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O solution was diluted to the saturated water absorption capacity of activated carbon, and was evenly dipped onto the activated carbon loaded with Pd metal in the previous step through a dropper. After sonication for 30 min, it was left at room temperature for 12 h and dried in a drying oven at 110 ℃ for 12 h. The final product is denoted as PdCu/AC. One-component 1%Pd/AC and 5%Cu/AC catalysts were prepared in the same way. The sintering process of the simulated catalyst is as follows: The PdCu/AC catalyst was placed in a calcination tube and calcined at 600 ℃ and N2 flow rate of 40 mL/min for 2 h, which was marked as PdCu/AC-S. The 1%Pd/AC and 5%Cu/AC single-component catalysts were treated in the same process, marked as Pd/AC-S and Cu/AC-S, respectively. 2.3 Redispersion of sintered catalysts The appropriate amount of sintered catalyst is loaded in the isothermal zone of the reaction tube. The catalysts were treated at T = 190 ℃ with a total flow rate of 160 mL/min (3.8% CO, 4% O2, and 92.2% Ar) for 2 h. The redispersed catalysts were labeled as PdCu/AC-R, Pd/AC-R and Cu/AC-R. In addition, the catalysts were treated at different O2/CO contents (1:2, 1:3, and 1:4). 2.4 Evaluation of CO oxidation activity The CO oxidation reaction was used as a probe reaction to determine the sintered catalyst redispersion effect. First, 0.5 g of sintered catalyst or redispersed catalyst was loaded in the isothermal zone of the fixed-bed reaction tube. The CO oxidation conversion of the catalyst was measured at T = 170 ℃ by passing a feed gas (3.8% CO, 4% O2, 92.2% Ar) at a flow rate of 160 mL/min. 2.5 Characterization of materials The crystalline phases of the samples were analyzed on an X'Pert PRO X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα-ray source (0.1541 nm) in the range of 10–80°, The operating voltage and operating current are 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The surface morphology and particle size of catalysts were studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of JEOL JEM-1200EX. Analysis of catalyst surface elemental valence and content using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) with an Al Kα-ray (hv=1486.6 eV) X-ray source. A Netzsch STA 409 thermo-analyzer was used for the thermogravimetric analysis of the catalyst. Before the experiment, the sample was purged with Ar gas at 110 °C for 1 h to remove the moisture from the sample, and then switched to the detection gas stream. During the measurement, the sample was heated at a rate of 10 ℃/min from 110 ℃ to 600 ℃. 2.6 Density functional theory calculations (DFT) The theoretical simulations in this paper were implemented using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) technology. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the interactions between the ions and the electrons with frozen-core approximation. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) electron exchange-correlation functional was adopted [21]. The adsorption process of CO oxidation was studied using Pd(111) crystalline surfaces and Cu-referenced PdCu(111) crystalline surfaces to construct a 4 × 4 × 3 atomic model with the first layer relaxed and the following two layers fixed. The stable point was identified by the conjugate gradient method until the forces acting on each ion were smaller than 0.05 eV/Å. The energy criterion for convergence of the electron density was set at 1 × 10−4 eV. The adsorption energy (Eads) is calculated as Eads=Etotal-ECO-EO2-EPdCu [22]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material structure and morphology The thermogravimetric analysis (TG) and micro-quotient thermogravimetry (DTG) of PdCu/AC catalyst under air atmosphere (30 mL/min) are shown in Fig. S1, The PdCu/AC catalyst has a weak weight loss peak between 100 ℃ and 165.6 ℃, which is due to the loss of water adsorbed on the surface of the carrier charcoal. There is a significant weight loss peak above 355 ℃, which corresponds to the combustion of the activated carbon itself. In this paper, the oxygen content in the redispersion atmosphere is 4% and the treatment temperature is less than 240 ℃, so the redispersion treatment conditions have almost no effect on the carbon carrier. Fig. 1 A shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of PdCu/AC-S catalyst, PdCu/AC-R catalyst, Pd/AC-S catalyst and Pd/AC-R catalyst, respectively. The results shows that PdCu/AC-S has six distinct diffraction peaks, among which the peaks at 2θ = 42.3°, 49.0° and 72.1° correspond to (117), (200) and (1117) crystal planes of PdCu3 alloy (PDF#07–0138), respectively, which confirms the formation of PdCu alloy in the PdCu/AC-R catalyst [23,24]. The Pd/AC-S catalyst has three distinct diffraction peaks at 40.2°, 46.8° and 68.3°, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of metallic Pd (PDF#87–0638) [25]. After the redispersion under COO2 atmosphere, the diffraction peak intensity and peak shape of metal Pd did not change significantly. 2θ = 43.2°, 50.3° and 73.9° diffraction peaks correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of Cu metal (PDF#70–3038), respectively, which indicates that in addition to the generation of PdCu alloy, there is still some Cu excess to form Cu crystals [26]. Comparing the catalysts (PdCu/AC-S and PdCu/AC-R) before and after the COO2 redispersion process, it was found that the PdCu diffraction peak shape was significantly broadened and the peak intensity was significantly weakened. The grain size of the catalysts calculated by Scheele's formula is listed in Table 1 . The grain size of PdCu alloy in the PdCu/AC-R catalyst was 16.4 nm, and the grain size of metal Pd in Pd/AC-S catalyst is 26.7 nm. After the COO2 redispersion treatment, the grain sizes of PdCu alloy and Pd were reduced to 7.4 nm and 26.3 nm, respectively. It indicates that the COO2 atmosphere could not redisperse the single-component sintered Pd/AC, while the catalyst obtained a significant redispersion effect when Cu was introduced to form the PdCu alloy. As shown in Fig. 1b, the size of PdCu nanoparticles in the PdCu/AC-S catalyst is about 18.8 nm, which is basically consistent with the XRD results. The characteristic signals of Pd and Cu particles are clearly displayed as seen in the EDX lines of Fig. 1c. The atoms are uniformly distributed and the Cu:Pd atomic intensity ratio is 3:1, indicating that the PdCu alloy has a uniform structure rather than a core-shell structure. Fig. 1d shows the mapping diagram of PdCu/AC-S catalyst, which shows that the PdCu alloy is uniformly dispersed on the carbon support. Fig. 2 shows the transmission electron micrographs (TEM) of PdCu/AC-S, PdCu/AC-R, Pd/AC-S and Pd/AC-R catalysts and their corresponding particle size statistical distributions. The metal particle size distribution ranges are listed in Table 1. The metal particles before and after the redispersion process of the sintered catalysts had relatively uniform sizes, with particle sizes of 18.8 ± 3.3 nm and 29.3 ± 6.7 nm for the PdCu/AC-S and Pd/AC-S catalysts, respectively. After the COO2 redispersion treatment, the metal particle sizes of the PdCu/AC-R and Pd/AC-R catalysts were 10.8 ± 3.1 nm and 30.6 ± 6.8 nm. This indicates that the PdCu/AC catalyst was successfully redispersed under COO2 atmosphere treatment, and the results obtained from the TEM plot statistics are consistent with the particle size calculated by the XRD Scheele equation. Therefore, it is concluded that only alloy PdCu/AC catalysts can be redispersed under the atmosphere treatment. The single-component Pd/AC catalysts cannot be redispersed. 3.2 Activity of CO oxidation High levels of carbon monoxide (CO) in the atmosphere represent a serious health and environmental problem, and catalytic oxidation of CO is one of the most effective technologies for removing pollutant [27–29]. The literature shows that the CO oxidation reaction is non-structure sensitive. The smaller the particle size of the catalyst, the higher the activity of the catalyst in a certain size range [30]. We used PdCu/AC-S and PdCu/AC-R catalysts to evaluate the performance in the CO oxidation reaction. Fig. 3 a shows the conversion rates of CO oxidation probe reactions before and after the redispersion at 160℃. The CO oxidation conversions of the catalysts were 5.9% and 35.8% before and after the redispersion of the PdCu/AC catalyst, and 3.3% and 3.1% before and after the redispersion of the Pd/AC catalyst, respectively. The catalytic activity of multiphase catalysts depends mainly on the metal dispersion [31,32], and catalysts with high metal dispersion are expected to provide more surface-active atoms for catalysis. The PdCu/AC catalyst showed significant redispersion after treatment, so the catalyst activity increased most significantly, while the Pd/AC catalyst did not show significant redispersion and the catalyst activity did not increase significantly. Fig. 3b shows the increase of CO oxidation activity from 27.5% to 51.2% for the PdCu/AC-S catalyst, from 2.4% to 6.2% for the Pd/AC-S catalyst, and from 24.2% to 39.0% for Cu/AC-S catalyst after redispersion at 170 °C. Fig. 3c shows the increase of CO oxidation activity from 34.2% to 99.7% for the PdCu/AC-S catalyst, from 16.7% to 17% for the Pd/AC-S catalyst, and from 32.1% to 67.8% for Cu/AC-S catalyst after redispersion at 180 °C. The effect of different ratios of CO/O2 atmosphere treatment catalysts on the CO oxidation reaction was also explored, as shown in Fig. 3d. The best redispersion effect was achieved when VCO:VO2 = 2:1 in the redispersion atmosphere, with 75% conversion in the CO oxidation reaction, while in the CO-rich atmosphere, the metal Pd active sites were covered due to the strong interaction force between Pd and CO, which made it difficult to continue the redispersion process. The CO conversion of the one-component Pd/AC catalyst was increased from 2.4% to 6.2%. The results showed that the Pd/AC catalyst treated under CO/O2 atmosphere neither improved the dispersion nor had almost no effect on the CO oxidation reaction. In addition, the CO conversion of Cu/AC catalyst was increased from 24.2% to 39.0%, which was due to the redispersion effect of Cu/AC catalyst under COO2 atmosphere treatment as well. Meanwhile, the influence of treatment time on the redispersion effect was investigated. As shown in Fig. S2, the metal particle sizes of the PdCu/AC-S catalyst were 6.6 ± 2.7 nm and 5.2 ± 1.3 nm after 4 h and 8 h treatment under COO2 atmosphere, respectively, which indicated that the treatment time of redispersion could control the relative size of the metal particle size. The particle size of the PdCu alloy decreased gradually with the increase of the redispersion time. In addition, the activity data of CO oxidation for 2 h, 4 h and 8 h were 53.3%, 71.9% and 75.8%, respectively, which gradually increased with the decrease of particle size. In addition, we further evaluated the activity of this catalyst in the hydrogen production reaction by formic acid decomposition, as shown in Fig. S3. The specific experimental conditions are shown in SI. In general, for the hydrogen production reaction by formic acid decomposition, small metal species have better catalytic activity compared to larger metal nanoparticles due to the increased number of active sites [33]. The PdCu/AC-S catalyst activity for formic acid decomposition to hydrogen production increased from 29.1% to 47.6%, and the catalytic activity increased significantly. In comparison, the activity of Pd/AC-S catalysts for the decomposition of formic acid to hydrogen was 26.5% and 27.8% before and after redispersion, respectively, with no significant change in activity, while the activity of Cu/AC-S catalysts for the decomposition of formic acid to hydrogen was 7.8% and 8.5% before and after redispersion, respectively, without showing significant activity for the decomposition of formic acid. 3.3 Redispersion process evolution The redispersion mechanism of supported noble metal catalysts is often accompanied by the formation of oxidative intermediates. These intermediate oxides can convert large particles of sintered noble metals into small nanoparticles. In order to further explore the valence states of Pd and Cu during the redispersion process of the sintered PdCu/AC catalysts [34], X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of Pd 3d and Cu 2p of the PdCu/AC-S and PdCu/AC-R catalysts were tested, as shown in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4a shows the Pd 3d XPS images of PdCu/A-S and PdCu/A-R catalysts, the Pd 3d XPS spectrum after Gaussian fitting consists of two major double peaks, indicating that the catalytic agent has two different Pd valence states [25,35]. PdCu/AC catalysts at two double peaks of Pd 3d5/2 (336.0 eV), Pd 3d3/2 (341.1 eV) and Pd 3d5/2 (337.4 eV), Pd 3d3/2 (342.6 eV), corresponding to Pd(0) and Pd(II), respectively. The PdCu/AC-S catalyst was treated with COO2 redispersion, in which the Pd(II) content increased from 13.8% to 69.0%, as shown in Table S1. Fig. 4b shows the Cu 2p XPS patterns of PdCu/AC-S and PdCu/AC-R catalysts. The Cu 2p3/2 (932.8 eV) and Cu 2p1/2 (952.6 eV) peaks in the Cu 2p XPS pattern in the PdCu/AC-S catalyst confirm the presence of metallic Cu [36,37]. Meanwhile, the peaks at Cu 2p3/2 (934.7 eV), Cu 2p1/2 (954.5 eV) and the satellite peaks at 941.6 eV, 944.5 eV confirm the existence of CuO. In addition, after the sintered catalyst was treated with COO2 redispersion, the content of Cu(II) increased from 32.9% to 60.0%. The results of Pd 3d and Cu 2p XPS indicated that the Pd and Cu were obviously oxidized during the redispersion process of the sintered PdCu/AC catalyst in COO2 atmosphere, and PdCu oxides were formed. In order to explore the role of the additive Cu in the redispersion process of the sintered PdCu/AC catalyst, the one-component sintered Cu/AC catalyst was treated with the same COO2 redispersion treatment. Fig. S4 shows the XRD patterns of the sintered Cu/AC-S catalyst and Cu/AC-R catalyst. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 43.2°, 50.3° and 73.9° in the sintered Cu/AC catalyst correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of metallic Cu (PDF#70–3038), respectively. However, after COO2 redispersion treatment, the diffraction peaks changed significantly. The four diffraction peaks 2θ = 36.4°, 42.3°, 61.4° and 73.6° of the Cu/AC-R catalyst correspond to (111), (200), (220) and (311) Crystal planes. It shows that the Cu/AC-S catalyst has obvious oxidation phenomenon after redispersion treatment. The particle size calculated by the Scherrer formula shows that the metal particle size of the Cu/AC catalyst before and after redispersion is 28.4 nm and 16.1 nm, respectively, indicating that the single-component Cu is not only oxidized after the redispersion treatment, but also the metal Cu particle size is significantly reduced. Meanwhile, the TEM images of the sintered Cu/AC catalyst before and after redispersion and the corresponding particle size distribution histogram are shown in Fig. S5. Larger Cu particles are surrounded by many small Cu particles. The particle size statistics of metallic Cu before and after redispersion were 22.8 ± 6.5 nm and 11.3 ± 3.1 nm, respectively, which were consistent with the XRD results. The surface of the large-grained metal Cu is oxidized, causing the surface Cu to break down and flake off, forming small pieces of CuOx intermediates. These intermediates migrate on the surface of the carrier, resulting in the redispersion of the sintered Cu/AC catalyst. 3.4 DFT calculation CO oxidation reactions generally follow the l-H mechanism or the MvK mechanism [38]. In the l-H mechanism, CO and O2 molecules are first adsorbed at different locations on the catalyst surface and then form intermediates on the surface to eventually produce CO2. To investigate the mechanism of catalytic reactions, the structures of CO and O2 molecules adsorbed on Pd (111) and PdCu (111) surfaces were calculated by density functional theory [39,40], the optimal adsorption model is shown in Fig. 5 . The bond lengths between the adsorbed molecules and the surface are shown in Table S2. The Pd-C bond length on PdCu/AC catalyst is slightly longer than that on Pd/AC catalyst during CO adsorption, while the Pd-O bond length did not change significantly between the PdCu/AC catalyst and the Pd/AC catalyst during O2 adsorption. The adsorption energies of O2, CO and CO2 on Pd (111) and PdCu (111) surfaces are shown in Table 2 . The adsorption of CO occurs only between the carbon atom and the surface of the alloy, and the oxygen atom is far from the surface, and CO adsorption on Pd (111) and PdCu (111) crystal surfaces were −2.08 eV and −1.24 eV, respectively. The adsorption energy of O2 on the Pd (111) and PdCu (111) crystal surfaces is −0.99 eV and −1.49 eV, respectively. It can be seen that the alloying of metals Pd and Cu weakens the adsorption energy of CO, while the doping of Cu improves the adsorption of O2. Theoretical studies have shown that Cu can strongly change the valence state of Pd by injecting an electric charge, and the result of this electronic modification is: Pd-Cu alloys are transformed from almost purely covalent (in the case of pure metals) to mixtures containing divalent Pd components by changing the nature of the interaction of CO with Pd surface centers and promoting the dissociation of CO with respect to Pd. Based on the Bader charge analysis, the charge transfer on the Pd(111) surface and the PdCu3(111) surface was explored. The introduction of Cu increased the amount of charge transfer and thus increased the reducing ability of Pd. In addition, the potential energy diagrams of Pd(111) and PdCu(111) surfaces are shown in Fig. 6 . The reaction of CO oxidation is divided into the breaking of O = O bond in adsorbed O2 and the combination of O atom and CO molecule to form CO2. The dissociation energies of O2 on Pd and PdCu are 1.19 eV and 0.55 eV, respectively, as shown in Table 3 . Meanwhile, the energy barriers for O and CO to form CO2 are 1.17 eV and 1.10 eV, respectively. This indicates that compared with pure Pd, the formation of PdCu alloy can effectively reduce the energy barrier of O = O bond breakage and promotes the catalytic activity between PdCu and CO oxidation. The strong preference of CO and O2 molecules on the surface of PdCu(111) for adsorption and the high adsorption energy of the surface allow them to form stable intermediates on the surface and react. Thus the CO oxidation reaction follows the l-H mechanism. 3.5 Redispersion mechanism The limitations of the single-component Pd/AC catalyst system for catalytic CO oxidation are: CO and O2 need to compete for the same Pd binding site, and the binding energy of CO to metal Pd is too high, leading to catalyst CO poisoning, making the catalytic performance of noble metal Pd catalyst system low [41]. The surface of Pd metal is covered by CO, so the efficiency of Pd metal active sites in adsorption and dissociation of O2 during CO oxidation is very low [42]. And the addition of a second metal may be an effective strategy to modulate catalytic performance by changing electronic and structural factors or to improve catalytic performance through bifunctional effects [43]. Two of the metal atoms provide catalytic sites for unique roles, such as separating different reactants or intermediates for adsorption. The Pd-Cu bimetallic catalyst system separate the binding sites of CO and O2 and reduce the activation energy of CO in the reaction pathway [44]. The same evidence has also been confirmed in the independent atmosphere treatment experiment, and the results are shown in Table S3. The CO oxidation activity of the catalyst varies from 27.5% to 34.3% in pure O2 atmosphere. The CO oxidation activity was 37.6% when the catalyst was treated with O2 atmosphere and then with CO atmosphere. The CO oxidation activity reached 51.2% when the catalyst was treated with CO/O2 at the same time. During the redispersion process, the oxidizing and reducing agents must be involved simultaneously. A schematic diagram of the sintered PdCu/AC catalyst redispersion process is shown in Fig. 7 . The sintering catalyst redispersion process is: the two-component PdCu/AC alloy catalyst can be effectively redispersed due to the doping of the additive Cu, and the metal Cu mainly plays the role of oxygen activation. CO and O2 are more readily adsorbed on the Pd and Cu active sites, respectively, and generate Oads on the Cu active metal surface atoms, which migrate to the neighboring Pd sites to form Pd-O species, and the formed Pd-O species easily migrate on the carrier surface to form small particle size PdCu alloys with the Cu on the carrier. 4 Conclusion This paper presents a method to regenerate sintered PdCu/AC catalysts by processing them under low temperature COO2 atmosphere treatment. After treating the sintered catalyst at 210 ℃ and CO-O2-N2 flow rate of 160 mL/min for 2 h, the catalyst showed significant redispersion. The redispersion mechanism of PdCu/AC catalysts was investigated by XPS and DFT theoretical calculation methods. Compared to metallic Pd, PdCu alloys can inhibit CO poisoning phenomenon as well as effectively reduce the energy barrier of CO oxidation reaction, which results in easier formation of possible PdCuOx intermediates by CO oxidation.The migration and reduction of PdCuOx intermediates lead to the gradual redispersal of PdCu alloy particles. This paper provides an effective strategy for the regeneration of sintered catalysts at low temperatures. coredata.dc:description: Loaded noble metal redispersion is an important way to solve catalyst sintering. However, how to redisperse at low temperatures or carbon-based noble catalysts is a difficult problem. In this paper, we report this phenomenon occurring on PdCu alloy catalysts, where small-sized PdCu alloys can be realized from sintered large-sized PdCu alloys on carbon supports in a CO/O2 atmosphere. The mechanism of redispersion is elucidated by XPS, TEM and DFT calculations. The main reason for the redispersion is the formation of the PdCuOx intermediate, which can easily migrate to the nearby catalyst surface and then be reduced to smaller PdCu alloy nanoparticles. This work provides a deeper understanding of the redispersion phenomenon and provides certain applications in industry.
coredata.dc:title: Redispersion of PdCu/AC sintered catalyst under CO-O2 atmosphere and mechanism study
